title: Drobin
text:
Drobin is a town in <a href="P%C5%82ock%20County">Płock County</a>, <a href="Masovian%20Voivodeship">Masovian Voivodeship</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, with 3,016 inhabitants (2004).
History.
The settlement was first mentioned in the 12th century, when it was part of <a href="Piast%20dynasty">Piast</a>-ruled <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Poland%20%281025%E2%80%931385%29">Poland</a>. It was granted town rights in 1511 under the <a href="Jagiellonian%20dynasty">Jagiellonian dynasty</a>. It was a <a href="private%20town">private town</a> of <a href="szlachta">Polish nobility</a>, administratively located in the <a href="P%C5%82ock%20Voivodeship%20%281495%E2%80%931793%29">Płock Voivodeship</a> in the <a href="Greater%20Poland%20Province%20of%20the%20Polish%20Crown">Greater Poland Province of the Polish Crown</a>.
A battle was fought nearby on August 15, 1920, during the <a href="Polish-Soviet%20War">Polish-Soviet War</a>.
During the <a href="Occupation%20of%20Poland%20%281939%E2%80%931945%29">German occupation of Poland</a> (<a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>), the Germans renamed the town "Reichenfeld" to erase traces of Polish origin, and operated a <a href="Forced%20labour%20under%20German%20rule%20during%20World%20War%20II">forced labour</a> camp there.
Sports.
The local <a href="Association%20football">football</a> team is Skra Drobin. It competes in the lower leagues.
External links.
